newsitem.title: UK: Cigarettes can help smokers think--Texan research.
newsitem.headline: Cigarettes can help smokers think--Texan research.

text.p: Smokers may have a point when they say lighting up helps them to concentrate, scientists in Texas reported on Wednesday.
They said there was a physical mechanism that underlies known effects of nicotine on memory and learning, and their findings could also shed light on the effects of Alzheimer's disease.

Reporting in the science journal Nature, John Dani and colleagues at Houston's Baylor College of Medicine said nicotine increases transmission of nerve impulses in the hippocampus -- the section of the brain involving learning and memory.
Dani's group worked with rat brains to simulate the process of smoking a cigarette -- during which nicotine reaches the brain 10 seconds after taking a puff.

They found that nicotine mimics the effects of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine, a chemical that helps carry signals across the synapses or spaces between brain cells. Acetylcholine stimulates the release of other neurotransmitters.
"We propose that nicotine from tobacco influences cognition by enhancing synaptic transmission," they wrote.
In the brain-wasting disease Alzheimer's, dementia sets in as acetylcholine disappears from the hippocampus. Dani's group said their work may shed light on the process.
